q: When should I start thinking about the vaccines I need?
i: If possible, see the GP or a private travel clinic at least 6 to 8 weeks before you're due to travel. Some vaccines need to be given well in advance to allow your body to develop immunity.
a: It is recommended to see a GP or a private travel clinic at least 6 to 8 weeks before your travel to allow time for necessary vaccines to be given and for your body to develop immunity.

q: Which travel vaccines do I need?
a: You can find out which vaccinations are necessary or recommended for the areas you'll be visiting on websites like Travel Health Pro and NHS Fit for Travel.

q: Where do I get my travel vaccines?
i: First, phone or visit the GP practice or practice nurse to find out whether your existing UK vaccinations are up-to-date.
a: You can get your travel vaccines from your GP practice, practice nurse, private travel vaccination clinics, or pharmacies offering travel healthcare services.

q: Which travel vaccines are free?
a: The following travel vaccines are available free on the NHS from your GP surgery: polio, typhoid, hepatitis A, and cholera.

q: Which travel vaccines will I have to pay for?
a: You will have to pay for travel vaccinations against diseases such as hepatitis B, Japanese encephalitis, meningitis, rabies, tick-borne encephalitis, tuberculosis (TB), and yellow fever. Yellow fever vaccines are only available from designated centres.

q: What other things should I consider when planning my travel vaccinations?
a: Other things to consider include your age, health conditions, occupation (working as an aid worker or in a medical setting), and contact with animals. It's also important to check if you're up-to-date with routine vaccinations available on the NHS.

q: What should I do if I'm pregnant or breastfeeding?
a: If you're pregnant or breastfeeding, it is advisable to speak to a GP before having any vaccinations for further advice.

q: What should people with immune deficiencies consider?
a: For people with immune deficiencies, vaccination against certain diseases may not be advised. It is recommended to consult with a GP for further advice.

q: Can I get non-travel vaccines during my travel vaccination appointment?
a: Yes, it is a good opportunity to ensure your other UK vaccinations are up-to-date and get booster vaccines if necessary. Consult with the GP about your previous vaccinations and whether you should have any additional ones.

q: Where can I find more information on NHS vaccines for adults and children?
a: You can find more information on NHS vaccines for adults and children to find out whether you should have any additional vaccinations.

q: When should I start thinking about the vaccines I need?
i: Ideally, see the GP or a private travel clinic 6 to 8 weeks before you travel to allow time for vaccinations.
a: If possible, see the GP or a private travel clinic at least 6 to 8 weeks before you're due to travel.

q: Which travel vaccines do I need?
a: You can find out which vaccinations are necessary or recommended for the areas you'll be visiting on websites like Travel Health Pro or NHS Fit for Travel.

q: Where do I get my travel vaccines?
i: Contact your GP practice or practice nurse to check if your existing UK vaccinations are up-to-date. They may be able to provide general advice about travel vaccinations and health, as well as any missing doses of your UK vaccines.
a: First, phone or visit the GP practice or practice nurse to find out whether your existing UK vaccinations are up-to-date.

q: Which travel vaccines are free?
a: The following travel vaccines are available free on the NHS from your GP surgery: polio (given as a combined diphtheria/tetanus/polio jab), typhoid, hepatitis A, and cholera.

q: Which travel vaccines will I have to pay for?
a: You'll have to pay for travel vaccinations against diseases such as hepatitis B, Japanese encephalitis, meningitis, rabies, tick-borne encephalitis, tuberculosis (TB), and yellow fever.

q: What should I consider when planning my travel vaccinations?
a: Consider factors like your age, health, occupation, and destination. Check if you need routine vaccinations available on the NHS and whether you'll come into contact with animals that can spread diseases.

q: Is it safe to get vaccinated while pregnant or breastfeeding?
a: Speak to a GP before having any vaccinations if you're pregnant, think you might be pregnant, or are breastfeeding. In most cases, vaccines given during pregnancy or breastfeeding are unlikely to cause problems, but consult a GP for advice.

q: Are travel vaccines recommended for people with immune deficiencies?
a: For individuals with conditions that affect the immune system or undergoing treatments that impact the immune system, travel vaccinations may not be advised. It's best to consult a GP for personalized advice.

q: Should I update my non-travel vaccines as well?
i: Let your GP know about your previous vaccinations to ensure they're up-to-date. You may also want to check if you're eligible for any additional vaccinations based on your risk group.
a: As well as getting any travel vaccinations you need, it's also a good opportunity to make sure your other UK vaccinations are up-to-date and have booster vaccines if necessary.

a: If possible, see the GP or a private travel clinic at least 6 to 8 weeks before you're due to travel.

q: Which travel vaccines do I need?
a: You can find out which vaccinations are necessary or recommended for the areas you'll be visiting on websites like Travel Health Pro and NHS Fit for Travel.

q: Where do I get my travel vaccines?
a: You can get travel vaccines from your GP practice, private travel vaccination clinics, or pharmacies offering travel healthcare services.

q: Which travel vaccines are free?
a: The following travel vaccines are available free on the NHS: polio, typhoid, hepatitis A, and cholera.

q: Which travel vaccines will I have to pay for?
a: You'll have to pay for travel vaccinations against diseases like hepatitis B, Japanese encephalitis, meningitis, rabies, tick-borne encephalitis, tuberculosis (TB), and yellow fever.

q: What should I consider when planning my travel vaccinations?
a: Consider factors such as your age, health, occupation, and destination. It's also important to check that you're up-to-date with routine vaccinations available on the NHS.

q: Should I get travel vaccinations if I'm pregnant or breastfeeding?
a: Speak to a GP before having any vaccinations if you're pregnant, think you might be pregnant, or breastfeeding. The GP will provide further advice.

q: Are travel vaccinations recommended for people with immune deficiencies?
a: For people with immune deficiencies, vaccination against certain diseases may not be advised. A GP can provide further advice based on individual circumstances.

q: Are non-travel vaccines available in addition to travel vaccines?
a: It's a good opportunity to ensure your other UK vaccinations are up-to-date and get booster vaccines if necessary. Certain risk groups may be offered extra vaccines.

q: Which non-travel vaccines are available?
a: Non-travel vaccines include those against diseases such as hepatitis B, tuberculosis (TB), flu, and chickenpox. Check NHS vaccines for adults and children for more information.
